Um, so what is it that cheats actually

Basically, what they have in common is

cheat, you can use what's commonly
called an aimbot and have the cheat just

whole process of getting good. And uh a
lot of people would say that takes the
fun out of the game. I would tend to
agree. Unfortunately, not everyone sees
that the same way.
Uh, another really important skill
mechanic is situational awareness or
like game sense more colloquially. Um,
you got to be really aware of the game

there are likely to be enemies or
unlikely to be enemies and you know plan

Uh, doing that requires a lot of
experience. You got to understand the

a lot of sneaky ways you can move around

a lot of brain work there. Uh but if you
use a cheat, for example, like what's

cheat can show you information about
players that you shouldn't have, and you
can sort of skip a lot of that skill
element. So, let's have a look at an

So that's an example of a cheat. Um how
do we categorize cheats?
One of the ways that we can do it,
there's a whole lot of options. One of
the ways we can do it is um just split
them into free and paid cheats is one of
the most simple ways. uh they both have
some things in common. One thing they
have in common is that there's a lot of
scams and malware, especially on the
free side. Um but both sides. Going
beyond that, there's some more
interesting and useful differences
between the two. Um
one of them is the update frequency. So
free cheats tend to be sort of like
dumped. People will usually upload them
once and then rarely or never update
them after that. Um and they don't do
any kind of user support typically
either. maybe a forum thread, possibly.
Um, on the page cheat sheet side,
assuming it's not a scam, they usually
are very frequently updated and they do
support through channels like Discord or
some other chat apps. Um,
there are uh, one really interesting
thing to know about free cheat sheets is
that they are sometimes actually
outdated or pirated versions of paid
cheats that are being distributed for
free. Um, pirated cheat is kind of like
a weird um, combo of words, but uh, page
cheats almost always have some kind of
copy protection or DRM because if they
don't, people will just use them without
paying for them, which is a problem that
a lot of game developers are familiar
with. Um, happens to cheat as well. So,
uh, in terms of what do I mean by paid
cheats, what is how do they actually
collect payment? Uh, they usually do
monthly subscriptions. That's the most
common way. Some of them do daily or
weekly subscriptions too, but they will
uh often operate in fairly professional
ways. They'll do things like um granting
extensions to subscriptions if the cheat
gets detected and they have to take it
down for an update or something like
that. So, they're very much businesses.
They're run like businesses. Uh
unfortunately, they make a profit at the
expense of legitimate players and
developers.
There's some differences in terms of
technical methods, too. for free cheats.
Uh, typically the technical methods are
much simpler. Um, usually if a cheater
comes up with a novel cheat method that
no one's used before and it's really
innovative, they'll want to make money
from it. So, it'll go into paid cheats
first and then eventually those kind of
trickle down into free cheat sheets once
they're more wellknown.
And generally speaking with technical
methods, paid sheets also because of
their update frequency and their
financial model, they can do higher

sometimes you'll see paid sheets that
have um they only work on one CPU
vendor, they only work on AMD or they
only work on Intel um or they only work
on one specific Windows version um which
is sort of like a a neat signal that
it's using some method that's very um
very customized and uh heavy maintenance
load.
All right, so that's what cheats are
trying to do. How can we actually
discourage them from succeeding in this?
Security is all about layers. Anti-che
is no different. There's no silver
bullet. There's no one thing you can do
that will prevent all the cheats. Um,
you got to have multiple layers and
hopefully that discourages attackers and
also sets a time limit on their success.
So, if they have a cheat that's
undetected and successful today, they
should be in doubt about whether the
same thing will be true tomorrow. Um, so
here's a few of the layers we do with
Fortnite.
One of them is of course is easy antiche
which is part of EOS. That's for cheat
prevention and detection. Easy antiche
works quite heavily at the system level
and it um is about sandboxing the
process and things like that. Um so to
supplement that this is something we
recommend in our documentation and uh I
want to recommend to you here too is
having game level antiche efforts for
Fortnite. We have a small team that's
dedicated to that. Uh some of the things
that they do includes handling game
exploits uh or cases where game clients
give are given too much authority. Um so
those are things that easy anti-che
can't really solve being that it's a a
general solution for cheating.
That team does a lot more other things
as well. Those are just a couple of good
examples. Then we have player reports
which is very useful as I alluded to
before. um individual player reports are
not very useful but in aggregate
statistically they're super useful. So
let's go ahead and talk about these
layers in more detail top to bottom
starting with EAC.
Prevention is extremely important for
EAC. It's sort of like a foundational um
philosophy for EAC. There's basically
two different ways you can respond to a
player cheating. One of them is
prevention which is proactive. So that
means in our perspective that the player
tried to cheat but it just didn't work.
Uh we don't punish them and hopefully
they just go back to playing the game
normally and having fun. Um the other
way you can respond is with detection
which is reactive. So that means that
the player did cheat uh you detected
them somehow and afterwards you punish
them usually with something like an
account ban. So when possible we think
prevention is better because other
players are not affected. doesn't
actually succeed uh the cheating
attempt. And you can avoid a negative
feedback loop where the players um
oftent times will go from having their
account banned to just creating new
accounts, especially in free-to-play
games. And um then the game for them
becomes not playing the game and having
fun, but rather ruining the game for
other people, which is bad for
everybody.
Um how do you actually implement
prevention? So, we think about this in
terms of limiting access to the game
process memory. There are some other
ways to cheat, but let's think about
that for today. Um, doing this
effectively on Windows really requires a
kernel driver, and Easy Antiche provides
that for you in a way that's well tested
and mature.
As with everything, uh, we're talking
about layers. So, no layer is perfect.
There are limitations to this. Uh, one
of the big limitations is that
prevention is mostly only effective
against free cheats because of the
update frequency. So for cheats that are
updated often, it's fairly easy for them
to test and see whether their cheat is
working or not. They can um basically
instantly know they try to run it, it
doesn't work, then they have to change
something in their cheat, run it again.
Um, so for paid sheets that are updated
often, detection tends to be more
important because there's more uh
opportunities to delay that feedback.
All right, what else can we do?
One thing that we started doing recently

are a lot of optional security features
in Windows that are they're not designed
to address cheating. They're designed to
address malware, but as a nice side
effect, a lot of cheats hide themselves
in the same way that malware does. So
these can make e uh antiche job easier.
And ideally, this should lead to a sort
of win-win situation for us where we ask
users to turn these on and the result is
that they become safer from malware and
our job becomes easier as anti-che.
The specific ones we're requiring now
for Fortnite are on the right there,
secure boot, which uh helps address a
lot of uh boot kit style cheats that
load early on in the boot process, and
then TPN, which is kind of like a meta
one. Um it helps us verify that other
settings like secure boot are enabled in
a way that's not easy to patch on the
client.
for the actual implementation. Uh the
things that we need there are knowledge
on the game client side of whether the

which requirements they are or are not

So if you have a check that's just on
the game client, it will not be

The implementation that we have is very
um
EAC is at the heart of it. These APIs

And um, you can do things like

When you're doing testing and QA and
